name: FORMAL LOGIC I

values.comments:
This course provides an introduction to some of the fundamental ideas of logic. Topics included truth functional logic, quantificational logic, and logical decision problems

Although the subject matter for the course was dense, theoretical, and “incredibly difficult”, students found the challenges of the class stimulating and well worth the effort. “This has proved the most…valuable class I\'ve ever taken,” one student said.

Professor Weinstein received unanimously positive reviews, and was described as “fun”, “engaging”, “entertaining”, and “very willing to help”. His office hours were a valuable, and practically essential component of doing well in the class.

The course, while listed as a requirement for a major in philosophy, seemed largely unconnected with the rest of the philosophy major. “Very little philosophy occurred,” one student said. Another commented that “most of the class felt like a class in discrete math.” One student mentioned that the class seemed most useful for logic, math or computer science studies. The class did require a significant amount of work outside of lecture, including regular attendance at office hours and tutorials.
